This game is very useful for testing the maps you make for Counter-Strike as it supports bots - you can check features related to 'various players in the map/spot/volume/etc.' with them when Online playtesting isn't an option.
la peor version... tiene sus cosas buenas pero son mas las cosas malas que tiene que las buenas

So.. I have to say this game is still playable. It's the same as 1.6 (I think) but with slightly different graphics. I play the deleted scenes more because it's more like a campaign. But this game is still sooo good. It has deleted scenes as I mentioned (campaign) and also something like a campaign but not in the deleted scenes version. I recommend you play this game and it's still fun in early 2k17.

Never before has a multiplayer game blended all the elements of true competition and sweat-soaked-shirt anxiety as well a Counter-Strike (CS). You probably already know CS as one of the most popular modifications for Half-Life. It's been available for download for over a year, at least in beta form. But unless you've got a super fast Internet connection at your house, you may not have played it yet as the nearly 100 megabyte download may be daunting for those of you not fortunate enough to have a high-speed connection. Thankfully CS has turned into a full-blown retail game and, while the two versions of CS are identical, it certainly worth shelling out $30 for this stellar title...plus you get a few more multiplayer goodies in the retail package to boot.

Let me start off by saying that the Counter-Strike pack is a stand-alone product. You don't need the original Half-Life to play this game. In the retail package you get a full version of CS as well as Team Fortress Classic, Opposing Force multiplayer, and the Wanted, Redemption and Firearms mods. The entire pack is overflowing with multiplayer fun, but, of course, the real focus of the retail release is Counter-Strike.

There is a single-player component to CS and, while it provides a good primer, this mod is all about online action. You basically play a game of cat and mouse, with the mouse being a terrorist group and the cat a squad of counter-terrorists. As a terrorist, you're goal is to plant a bomb at a specific location or hold a group of hostages. As a counter-terrorist, it's your duty to defuse said bomb or rescue the ill-fated hostages. Taking out all players on the opposing side will also assure your victory.

CS is an action lover's dream, with games lasting only four or five minutes (if that in some cases) because, unlike Half-Life, one shot to the head can mean instant death. CS is the perfect mix between fast-action and realistic damage. You can't just absorb bullet after bullet and expect to walk away. Working as a team is a must and, while you're in the game, taking the lone wolf approach will often get you killed...and fast.

It's the team-based tactics that make CS so fun. I can't stress how important it is in this game to act as a team. If your team is on the defensive side you'll all benefit by creating a cohesive strategy. If you team is on the offensive side, you will all benefit by sticking closely together as well. I'm sure you've seen movies or television show demonstrating this "Conga Line" style of infiltration. Well, that's exactly how your team will have to act. This creates a fantastic game balance that will keep you coming back for more. It'll also keep you from thinking about your school work, your job, and interaction with your loved ones, and often work around the IGN offices will be put on hold so we can clog our network with CS.

Visually the game will not disappoint. While the Half-Life engine isn't the prettiest beast out there, there is plenty of animation that creates a smooth look and feel, and the gun models are some of the most realistic looking of any shooter available. The environmental textures look realistic enough and complement the provided camouflage well enough for you to be hidden, but not be invisible. As in real life, the distinguishable difference between good guy and bad guy is a little difficult, but the balance to this is if you can't tell who it is then you probably won't be able to hit him with your gun. Now, if you've purchased sniper rifle, you should have plenty of scope magnification to tell the difference between terrorist or counter-terrorist, but otherwise you may be taking out a team member from afar.

As good as it is, a couple of features of this game really stood out as frustrating... at first. But over a period of time they actually became enhancements to online multiplayer gaming. One feature is buying your weapons at the start of each round. This takes a little getting used to at first since, in most shooters, you just run around picking up weapons at your heart's content. Usually by the time you figured out which guns, grenades, and armor you were going to take in your early games, the bad guys would come over and kill you. But a couple of tries later, after getting the gist of things, you're off in no time. The other feature that took some getting used to was the "wait and watch" feature after you get killed. Once you sustain a lethal injury, you have to wait for the next round to start before you can join in again -- you don't just spawn again and start shooting. This actually adds a ton of anxiety to your efforts of staying alive and completing your objective. But like I mentioned before, the rounds are short, so you shouldn't have to wait too long before you can jump in the action again.
Idiotisk og kaste meg ut, midt i spillet pga dere vil ha en anmeldelse av spillet.

Un cl√°sico genial.
Es un juegazo sin lugar a dudas.
Misones geniales y partidas contra bots y en servidores.
Merece ma pena, sobre todo si lo compras en rebajas.

Conditon Zero es un producto Counter Strike, y eso ya le asegura un cierto √©xito. Pero el caso es que se edita tarde y llega de puntillas, sin que quede ni rastro de la revoluci√≥n que pudo haber sido. Para entender por qu√© este proyecto ha acabado descarrilando, basta con darle un repaso a su dif√≠cil g√©nesis. Ritual Entertainment empez√≥ haci√©ndose cargo del desarollo bajo la supervisi√≥n de Valve, pero a los creadores de Half-Life no les gust√≥ un pelo lo que estaban haciendo. Les retiraron el proyecto y lo pusieron en manos de Gearbox, los autores de Counter Strike. Sin embargo, su enfoque (una larga campa√±a individual con hilo narrativo) tampoco les convenci√≥, y optaron por encargar a Turtle Rock que hiciese una versi√≥n del mod original a√±adi√©ndole bots inteligentes. Para este viaje, no hac√≠an falta alfombras.

Lo que queda
Algo s√≠ de lo hecho por Ritual y Gearbox. Junto al Condition Zero propiamente dicho, incluye las llamadas Deleted Scenes (escenas borradas), que no son sino los restos de lo que iba a ser la campa√±a individual. Se trata de una serie de misiones aisladas que se desarrollan en distintos puntos del planeta y que enfrentan a los grupos terroristas y fuerzas del orden de cada zona concreta.

En ese esbozo de campa√±as se pueden apreciar algunas de las novedades de Condition Zero, como la mejora gr√°fica respecto al mod Counter Strike. No es que sea ninguna proeza si lo comparamos con los est√°ndares actuales, pero sin duda se trata del mejor derivado del motor de Half-Life. Las misiones son nada del otro mundo y se nota en exceso que forman parte de un proyecto inacabado. Las peores tal vez sean las de sigilo, nada adaptadas al esp√≠ritu de juego de Counter Strike. Se dir√≠a que no son m√°s que una excusa para utilizar nuevos aparatos como el cable de fibra √≥ptica o la radio, que s√≥lo funcionan en puntos concretos del mapa.

Lo m√°s probable es que este simple esbozo de partida en solitario te aburra y prefieras centrarte en el modo al estilo del Counter Strike de toda la vida. Si lo haces, ver√°s que incluye mapas nuevos (no muchos) y mejoras en las texturas. Sin embargo, nada de todo esto resulta una verdadera novedad, ya que tanto los mapas adicionales como las nuevas texturas y armas han sido incluidos en las actualizaciones de Counter Strike aparecidas mientras Condition Zero estaba en desarrollo.

Tipos duros
Tal vez el gran aliciente sea jugar con los bots ‚Äúoficiales‚Äù, mucho mejores que los rivales computerizados que puedes descargarte gratis en Internet. En los niveles de dificultad altos, topas con aut√©nticos humanoides de letal punter√≠a. Para superar un mapa, debes ganar en las tres primeras rondas o conseguir una ventaja de dos rondas a partir de la tercera. Como complemento, dispones de una serie de objetivos secundarios obligatorios destinados a perfeccionar tu t√©cnica (ganar una ronda en un tiempo limitado, acabar con un enemigo con determinada arma, rescatar un n√∫mero concreto de rehenes‚Ä¶).

Son peque√±as variantes que, en definitiva, se resumen en lo siguiente. La posibilidad de invertir los puntos e ir formando un equipo de especialistas para que te acompa√±en da un aliciente adicional a esta algo casina f√≥rmula. Antes de cada misi√≥n, debes hacer acopio de los puntos disponibles y decidir si los inviertes en profesionales m√°s caros o m√°s baratos.

Hecho esto, ya s√≥lo quedan los combates entre terroristas y antiterroristas. Mientras duren, tus compa√±eros te informar√°n de la posici√≥n que ocupan y de lo que hacen en todo momento y obedecer√°n tus √≥rdenes‚Ä¶ si consigues que conf√≠en en ti. En el apartado multijugador, Condition Zero recurre al ya estandarizado Steam, que permite jugar partidas con las versiones actualizadas del mod. En fin, un intento tard√≠o de inyectar algo de sangre a un mod excelente pero que ya conoci√≥ tiempos mejores.

Inteligencia de quita y pon
Est√° claro que el principal atractivo de Condition Zero son sus bots. Algo tendr√°n que los diferencien de los que puedes encontrar en Internet para justificar el largo desarrollo del juego. Su secreto es que est√°n programados para recorrer cualquier mapa nuevo recopilando los datos necesarios para moverse por ellos. Estos datos se guardan en un archivo que pueden ser distribuido entre los jugadores para ahorrar el trabajo de exploraci√≥n a los dem√°s.


Es Counter Strike, s√≠, y conserva intacta su jugabilidad. Sin embargo, se edita con tanto retraso y tan pocas novedades de fuste respecto al mod que no queda m√°s remedio que hablar de peque√±a decepci√≥n. Adem√°s, muchos jugadores empiezan a darle la espalda en beneficio de otras propuestas on line.

Sunday 24th September 2017 20:11/Sunday 12th November 2017 20:40
(for Deleted Scenes) Good game so far, a nice half-life style take on a CS campaign (better than the regular game, or I suck at CS in general...), however I did encounter problems with Building Recon: a staggering 4 headshots with the Scout in order to kill the leader. That's more than I can do at medium range behind cover and with a nuke beeping away. Tip: cheat code 'notarget'.

After completing the campaign, it is pretty hard but at least is a bit better than CS:CZ's one since I suck at Counter-Strike. As much as I suck, maybe it would be wise to list a few quirks in order to play this game: [spoiler]Use knife to get through vents, branches (Downed Pilot). On Hankagai, use the blue (crates? boxes?) in order to get over fences or to the vent.[/spoiler] When you discover everything you need to know about the game, it can be quite playable but there is still the problem of lack of armour most of the time (therefore a reliance on medical supplies) and that the enemies appear to be quite accurate, which only exarceberates the previous problem. Then again, I suck at Counter-Strike so what would you expect?

Como casi el 99% de usuarios de Steam sabr√°n de qu√© trata el Counter-Strike en apartado multijugador, me remitir√© a analizar lo que nos ofrece el imprescindible Counter-Strike: Condition Zero en sentido innovador:

El CS:CZ cuenta con dos juegos, el original y el Deleted Scenes, los cuales vienen separados en la biblioteca de Steam:

- El Condition Zero original es el Counter-Strike de toda la vida, solo que cambian las skins de los personajes y poco m√°s. El multijugador cuenta con varios mapas nuevos (basados en los niveles de Deleted Scenes) adem√°s de los cl√°sicos de Counter-Strike. Sigue estando bastante activo gracias a los servidores dedicados.
 
Tambi√©n cabe destacar la introducci√≥n de un modo de misiones individuales a modo de desaf√≠os, donde tendremos la posibilidad de reclutar un equipo de BOTs con puntos (los cuales obtenemos al completar misiones, siendo cada vez mayor el n√∫mero de puntos necesarios para conseguir un BOT experto en habilidades en nuestro equipo). Se trata de una partida offline en diversos mapas donde tendremos que realizar una serie de determinados objetivos variados (matar a un enemigo cegado, X bajas con Y arma...). Existen cuatro niveles de dificultad, en los cuales aumenta el n√∫mero de requisitos (matar m√°s con X arma en general y rescatar a todos los rehenes

- El Condition Zero: Deleted Scenes nos ofrece algo totalmente innovador dentro de la saga Counter-Strike: un modo campa√±a. Dicho modo consiste en un mapamundi con alrededor de 15 misiones individuales donde nos pondremos en la piel de diferentes equipos t√°cticos (SWAT, GIGN...) para llevar a cabo misiones antiterroristas (como rescatar rehenes, matar a l√≠deres terroristas, destruir una f√°brica de droga, sabotear una base...). 

En definitiva, el CZ lo recomiendo exclusivamente y sobre todo por la campa√±a, ya que los amantes de Half-Life sentir√°n mucha nostalgia al jugarlo. El multijugador es un cl√°sico y las misiones con BOTs presentan un buen reto para mejorar.

[h1]8/10[/h1] Mejor doblaje al espa√±ol ever. #Memeo
